thread.title: High school stoner claims hack of CIA director's AOL email
thread.title_full: High school stoner claims hack of CIA director's AOL email

author: Cheryl Chumley
title: High school stoner claims hack of CIA director's AOL email
text:
Text bigger John Brennan 
A high school student who hasn’t been identified said in several interviews with the New York Post he’s hacked into CIA director John Brennan’s private AOL email account, and accessed private data on intelligence officers. 
A Twitter account reportedly affiliated with the hacker – called “cracka” and referencing the acronym “CWA,” or “Crackas With Attitude” – has been posting links about Brennan’s contact list and about call logs of Avril Haines, a deputy national security advisor, the Daily Mail reported. 
Get the hottest, most important news stories on the Internet – delivered FREE to your inbox as soon as they break! Take just 30 seconds and sign up for WND’s Email News Alerts! 
Brennan’s email was supposedly hacked on Oct. 12 when Verizon workers were reportedly tricked into releasing his private and personal information. 
“We are not doing this for personal satisfaction, we’re doing this for #FreePalestin and #FreeGaza,” the Twitter account of the supposed hacker said in response to a question from the Daily Mail Online about the motives for the hack. 
The supposed hacker told the New York Post he’s a marijuana smoker. 
The CIA is investigating. 
“We are aware of the reports that have surfaced on social media and have referred the matter to the appropriate authorities,” the CIA said in a statement, the Daily Mail reported. 
Among the information found in Brennan’s AOL account were Social Security numbers of a dozen top American intelligence officials and his own 47-page application for a top security clearance, the New York Post reported. 
See what American education has become, in “Crimes of the Educators: How Utopians Are Using Government Schools to Destroy America’s Children.” 
A source told the newspaper: “I think they’ll want to make an example out of [this hacker] to deter people from doing this in the future. … I can’t believe he did this to the head of the CIA. [The] problem with these older-generation guys is that they don’t know anything about cyber=security and as you can see, it can be problematic.” Text smaller
